If you integrate ENS and submit for the ENS prize, **please explain on your project description page how you integrated ENS (could even be one sentence)**. If I have to go searching through your dapp for how you integrated ENS, you're unlikely to win our prize.

Two easy ways to integrate ENS:
- **Reverse Resolution**: If you display a 0x address anywhere (e.g. after the user connects their wallet), do a reverse look-up and display the user's ENS name in their reverse record instead: https://docs.ens.domains/dapp-developer-guide/resolving-names#reverse-resolution

- **Forward Resolution**: In any field in which a person might enter a cryptocurrency address, enable the user to also enter an ENS name: https://docs.ens.domains/dapp-developer-guide/resolving-names#looking-up-ethereum-addresses

- Lots of other things you could do with ENS so feel free to experiment or do more, but these two are easy and apply to most dapps

2. The actual metadata that gets returned from the tokenURI function of your NFT contract won't change (unless it's actually updated on-chain, if the contract allows that). But inside that metadata the `image` could potentially point to a web2 server hosting the image, and the centralized provider of that server could change the image that gets served up. Sort of defeats the point of decentralization obviously, but there are still NFTs out there that function this way.

If the metadata points to an IPFS content hash then that won't change. But there are other non-standard metadata formats out there too like Async Art's which seek to do exactly that - dynamic images. Like someone showed me this NFT of the moon that changes dynamically depending on the time of day. https://async.art/art/master/0xb6dae651468e9593e4581705a09c10a76ac1e0c8-3447

You can view the metadata for that here ipfs://Qmcvm5ddzgwQvdubTNoKRwJpUitLFT5Wo2PvWetsmZUB5M . You'll see that the `image` just points to the default new moon state, but the actual dynamic pieces are in a custom `layout` field that isn't supported by the ERC-721 or ERC-1155 standards. So on most sites the avatar would just show up as just a black circle. But theoretically a client dapp could support ENS primary names with dynamic avatars like that if they wanted. Same as how a client could support rendering MP4 file avatars if they wanted to (I think Rarible does this with some of their own custom contracts).

In most cases, a client website/dapp, like OpenSea, is going to request the avatar from the ENS metadata service and then cache it on their own storage. That's why they also have a Refresh Metadata option. It's a tradeoff they make for efficiency I suppose.
